article.description: Richard Hendrix scored 28 points and pulled down 14 rebounds Tuesday night to lead Alabama to a 90-83 victory over Mercer, the Bears unable to follow up their stunning win over Southern Cal with another surprise against a major-conference team.

images.name: Hendrix_Richard 071113 [200x300]
images.caption: Richard Hendrix was just too much to handle for Mercer's small frontline.

related.description: Mercer was out to prove the shocking upset win over USC was no fluke. Unfortunately for the Bears, Alabama's Richard Hendrix got in the way of the feel-good story, writes Mark Schlabach.
related.linkText: Schlabach: Despite loss, Mercer still impresses
related.title: Hendrix too much for Mercer to duplicate USC upset
related.headline: Hendrix too much for Mercer to duplicate USC upset

article.headline: Alabama overpowers Mercer in front of sellout crowd
article.linkText: Hendrix, Alabama prove too much for tiny Mercer
article.story: MACON, Ga. (AP) -- Richard Hendrix scored 28 points and pulled down 14 rebounds Tuesday night to lead Alabama to a 90-83 victory over Mercer, the Bears unable to follow up their stunning win over Southern Cal with another surprise against a major-conference team. Mercer (1-1) drew the first sellout crowd in the history of their 3,200-seat campus arena, which opened in January 2004, but they simply had no one to stop the 6-foot-8, 255-pound Hendrix. He hit 11-of-15 shots from the field and led the Crimson Tide (2-0) to a dominating performance on the boards. Hendrix pulled down six of his rebounds at the offensive end, leading Alabama to a 50-32 advantage over the shorter Bears. Hendrix also had three blocks and two steals. Plus, his presence on the inside opened up shots on the perimeter for the Southeastern Conference team, which made 8-of-18 from beyond the arc. After James Florence hit a 3-pointer that pulled Mercer to 57-55 with 12 1/2 minutes remaining, Justin Tubbs countered at the other end with a trey to spark an 8-0 spurt that restored the double-digit lead. Florence, who scored 30 points in the win over USC, failed to come up with another big effort. He had 22 points but mainly because he kept firing up shots, hitting just 7-of-22 from the field. He was an abysmal 1-of-10 outside the 3-point arc. Mercer, a Baptist-affiliated private school with little athletic tradition, was buzzing with excitement after perhaps the biggest win in school history, the 96-81 upset of then-No. 18 Southern Cal last Saturday. Hundreds of students gathered outside the University Center hours before the game, tailgating and listening to bands. Most of the student body hung around to the end, saluting their team with one final cheer as they headed off the court with their heads down. Last season, the Atlantic Sun team drew an average of just over 1,000 a game. Alonzo Gee had 16 points for Alabama, and Mykal Riley added 11. Freshman Senario Wilkinson, who played his high school ball about a half-hour away at Wilkinson County, chipped in with 9 points to thrill a large contingent that came to see him play. SEC teams rarely go on the road to face low-level schools such as Mercer, but Alabama coach Mark Gottfried scheduled the unusual road trip as part of a two-for-one deal that will bring the Bears to Tuscaloosa twice. He wanted to boost the Tide's recruiting profile in central Georgia and give Wilkinson a chance to play before the home folks. But Hendrix was the star of the show, especially with Mercer's burliest player, 6-8, 245-pound Sam Dolan, sitting out because of an ailing back. Shaddean Aaron also had 22 points for the Bears, and Brian Pfohl added 15.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.
